description:
What a Mexican foodies dream that I found in San Francisco! Parking can be hard to find but about a block away there is a park and unlimited parking! Around the area is 2 hours.

What we ordered:

Menudo 5/5 - hubby has been craving for menudo since forever and we have finally found the spot! Authentic homemade corn tortillas come as a side to this flavor packed soup! They are not cheap at all with the tripe and inners for this soup! The large is soooo worth it and you can take some home! Definitely A+ standards!

Pozole 5/5 - oh man I've made homemade Pozole before with an authentic recipe from mi suegra in Mexico but this is as good as it can get in the Bay Area! Yummers! Couldn't finish the big bowl but I took some home! So worth is since a small is 8oz and large is 24oz! 

Kids Cheese Quesadilla 3.5/5 - home made corn tortilla with queso with some sour cream slathered on top. It was served w a side of fresh veggies and toasted crispy with cheese oozing out! My kiddo ate 1/2 of it but she slammed two homemade tortilla in her belly 

Homemade tortilla 5/5 - soooo fresh and good it was delicious!!!!!

Overall definitely coming back. The hospitality and service and food was amazing! Can't wait to see what else is good here next time!!!
author: Victoria U.

description:
Came here today and was waited on by a very nice server. Sat down and ordered lunch which came out pretty quickly. The food was sort of mediocore I ordered a chicken taco salad.

I gave two stars to this place for the nice staff and decent food. My main issue with this place was that I sat next to a column and it wreaked of a combination of mop water and wet dog................. Not what I want to smell as I eat.
author: Michael W.

description:
Went there with friends and our kids. First, the food is all very tasty - I wish there was more vegetarian options to enjoy! The veggie super burrito was great anyway. 
For the kids, some shared a burrito and the staff brought it precut in two separate plates! How convenient and helpful. 
Then, someone - the owner? the manager? - came by and asked if everything was alright and ordered us some extra quesadillas, cheese and beans. We got out of there our bellies full and happy having been so warmly welcomed. I will come back!
author: Pierre-Luc B.

description:
Finally! I have finally found a solid menudo place in San Francisco. With great prices, delicious food and quick service this place was an awesome find. Do note that they are cash only!

The menudo was delicious. Not as good as the ones I've had in SoCal, but the best I've been able to find in the bay area thus far. The soup was rich and flavorful with plenty of tripe pieces. They gave generous portions of the oregano, lime, onions, crushed chili and cilantro. And the whole thing was just nicely cooked, rich and delicious.

For a large portion it was only $11, which I've come to learn is quite a steal in San Francisco nowadays!
author: Tyler T.

description: Excellent, authentic, homemade Mexican food. You can taste the love they put into it. The salsa is handmade each morning and is spicy hot!  The caldo de res (beef soup) is perhaps their signature dish and, dare I say, a hangover cure. The corn tortillas are delicious beyond compare. The staff is super friendly.
author: George S.

description:
Wow what a great find!!!!
Authentic and good at every corner
We had chili relleno, carrot-orange juice and carnitas 
Seems like lots of folks had the soups and shrimp cocktail, which we were just too full to get but looked great.
!!!
author: D R.

description: The food was amazing and the atmosphere is great. Got the pozzole and it came with a lot of meat! My cousin also got a plate which was packed with lots of flavor! Def a great stop to stop and eat! Also the owner seems very genuine and kind.
author: Nadia D.

description:
I totally wanted to get soup from here, but I didn't have enough cash on me and ended up getting a Carne Asada Burrito with what every loose bills and change I could find in my bag/car.  I didn't have my wallet on me because I came from working out next door and I was STARVING.  I was short by a quarter and they were kind enough to understand and let me have a burrito.

It's very authentic in here, everyone speaks Spanish and they were watching some kind of telanovela on the screen.  Next time I'll come back with enough money to get the soup!

CASH ONLY
author: Lyn C.

description: Been here a handful of times and their Pozole never disappoints. Good Micheladas just tell them to take it easy with the Lea & Perrins sauce. Its a cash only restaurant which kind of sucks because I hardly ever carry cash. Other than that food is good and definitely my go to for the hangover cure :)
author: Vee N.

description:
This is easily one of my favorite Mexican restaurants. The staffs are super friendly and generous. We went for lunch with a group of 10+ people. The fact that they accept reservations makes it very effortless and convenient. A few minutes into us sitting down at our table, baskets of chips and bowls of salsa & guac were placed onto our table for us to snack on. Shortly after, we noticed we might have some additional colleagues joining us so we asked for if we could add another table to the end. The staff was extremely accommodating and understanding. Two of the colleagues got the pozole which looked absolutely mouthwatering. I'm definitely trying that next time. Many of us got the combination plates with the many different options, such as two enchiladas or one enchilada with a tostada, etc. The food is delicious and the portions are huge. Most of us struggled to finish the combination plate. 

We were celebrating two birthdays and the restaurant staffs were so kind to celebrate with us. They surprised our table with a plate of fried plantains and flans! It also happened to be the first day of Autumn for their culture so they decorated the dessert plate with a lot of fall colors and topped it with two candles. 

It's hard to believe that the bill only came out to $170 with tax and tips included for a table of 12! It's so hard to find good food at a decent price in the City nowadays, so I'm so happy that Gallardos offers the best of both worlds!
author: Linda H.

description:
I'm Mexican so I've had more than a few bowls of pozole. 

I walked in on a cold rainy day and ordered this places signature dish and I was not disappointed.

What I liked in particular is that they didn't skimp on the sides. Several wedges of lemon , a ton of chopped onion , tortillas and a tostada. 

All of this came out to roughly 11 bucks after tax. 

The broth was excellent as was the hominy.  The soup came out quickly which is a sign that they make a lot as well. 

All in all a great experience , I look forward to returning when I have a pozole craving.
author: Rod M.

description:
This place is a religious experience. I came here sick because I was craving some pozole and this place blew my mother effing mind and overdelivered on flavor.

*Food*
I got the pozole and a horchata- internally asking myself if it would be worth getting a cold drink since all I could taste was my own snot. They started me off with some crisp, perfectly oiled, housemade tortilla chips and salsa served from a plastic container for you to spoon on to your chips, not for dip. The salsa is spicy, leaving me drinking 3/4 of my horchata before even getting my pozole - but tasty enough for me to finish my basket of chips with the fresh squishy blocks of tomato from the salsa. The horchata tasted housemade, not too sweet, and with the nice grit you expect from OG-non-artificial horchata. 

Shortly before my pozole arrived, my server stopped by my table to give me 3 stacked wooded plates. On top were limes, under that oregano, and under that some hot looking spice that I assume was Achiote. Please correct me as I am a pozole amateur. They were also substantial amounts of spices that I definitely was not going to use for my soup. But she didn't stop there, she handed me a plate with shaved cabbage, radishes, sour cream, and tostadas. AND THEN, a container for 3 hot and fresh tortillas.

THEN my pozole arrived which was a hot, warm, steamy, good for the soul soup. In my heart I immediately thought, DAMN I'm going to be full af after all this food and VALUE MEAL. Feel free to split this meal with 1-2 other people. 

I spiced my soup to taste, I like it extra tart so I squished all the lime wedges, enough to make a baby's face pucker up. A little BAM of the oregano and a little BAM of the achiote. Nobody looked at me and thought I was weird because this in San Francisco for crying out loud. 

And then I took a heaping spoonful of the soup, put it in my mouth, and I was sent all the way back to Mexico City. Life was compelte and in that moment I felt that all of my illness was gone. Praise be. The meat in the soup came off the bone and on the bone, suggesting you to place it on top of the crisp tostada, dabbing it with some sourcream goodness and the light and fresh cabbage. Crunch after crunch, sip after sip my soup disappeared until I saw an empty bowl with red and green specs of spice. And in that moment my heart sank only to realize that it was all over. 

I looked up to realize that the entire restaurant had turned over. What a roller coaster of emotions. 

Come eat here if you want your hear, soul, and belly nourished.
author: Geronimo Carlo R.

description:
OHMAGOD was the Pozole delicious! I was debating between enchiladas and the Pozole, and the server recommended the Pozole, so I was in.

Food came out pretty quick, and the server was super helpful when my friend and I were trying to figure out what to eat. I got a small bowl of Pozole, but didn't realize how much additional fixings it came with! I added in some radish, onion, cilantro, and a squeeze of lime. The pork was super soft, and I'm usually not a huge fan of pork. The radish and onions added a nice crunch with every bite, and I felt there was the right amount of hominy.

The soup was less than $10, which is SUCH a steal! I can't wait to be back!
author: Daisy Y.

description:
I was recommended to go here for the best menudo in SF. They do have great menudo and an even friendlier staff. I love this place. The decor of famous Mexican actors is a classic touch.

I would recommend this place to anyone
author: Daniel C.

description: This place serves good Mexican home style plates, donde common Mexican fast food. Just cash, be prepared and prices are affordable. I had ranchero steak
author: Victorya Esmeralda L.

description:
I was debating between coming here for a big bowl of Menudo or Birria al Horno.
after about 2 minutes of contemplation, I decided to go for a large bowl of Menudo.
let me tell you, it's a lot of tripes!
I squeezed all the limes, put all the chopped onions and cilantro, and I just went straight at it.
it's okay, it's a weekend.
the food was good, the ambience was really warm and hospitable, the service was courteous, the bill was reasonable.
I would come here again to try different things.
and I would come here again if I have a Mexican girlfriend,
Definitely.
author: Rudy H.

description:
Great place for huge portions of authentic Mexican food. We came in for breakfast and ordered the cactus, potato, and chorizo scrambles which came generously portioned with rice and beans and warm tortillas. However everyone around us seemed to be there for the soups. That'll have to be for next time...

The place got packed quickly with the locals and a gentleman came into serenade the customers toward the end of our stay. 

We enjoyed the quick service and the spicy chunky salsa that was the perfect complement to my chorizo scramble for heat and freshness. I also got the fresh carrot juice which was a nice way to start my morning.

*cash only
*a couple outdoor tables available
*seems to be a hot spot for the local Mexican community
author: Sarah M.

description:
Had a very greasy and very soggy spinach quesadilla with a side of rice and beans. That and the sour cream and guacamole all sort of ran together in an unappetizing puddle in the plate. I rarely leave food behind but I wasn't inspired to box up the leftovers to take home.

I'm sure there are better things on the menu - my friend had a burrito that looked fine - but the cooking seemed sloppy. 

Other small details that on their own wouldn't bother me added up to a disappointing experience. There were charred meat scraps on the quesadilla - not an issue for me, but could be for someone with food restrictions. Prices listed on menu were incorrect. Cash only, though this was not apparent, and a $30 bill seems a bit much for cash only. Service was pleasant but not particularly attentive, especially given that there were not many other diners. Styrofoam take-out containers. Again, nothing earth-shattering but all together less than stellar.

The jugo mixto carrot-orange juice was good and a generous size, which I appreciated.

Sad we stopped in here when there's so many great places to eat in the neighborhood.
author: Jeanne M.

description:
Food: 3/5
Service: 4/5
Ambiance: 3/5
Overall:  wasn't completely impressed.  the food is ok and serves as another option in the neighborhood.  

The extended review:

Food:

Carne guisado - the dish was ok but perhaps I'm more used to the stew that is more from the islands (Cuba, PR, and DR).  There wasn't an abundance of meat unfortunately but it was enough to get me sort of full.

Service: super friendly waitstaff though we took our orders to go.

Ambiance: a slight step up from hole in the wall.
author: Spencer Q.

description:
I've loved this restaurant for over 20 years. Sadly I don't get over to this part of the city very often or can I still do justice to the generous portions that they serve. 

Skip the standard fare that you can get all over town, the enchiladas or burritos; I'm sure they are good, maybe even excellent. But the reason to come to Gallardos is for the amazing soups or the birra -- when they have it -- or the other more homey fare. Look out for bones, just chew around them and set them aside; the meat surrounding them is all the more flavorful for having been cooked on the bone.
author: Eli C.

description:
I woke up this morning with a craving for Pozole. As all my friends in Mexico repeatedly told me when I lived in DF, "Mexican food in the US isn't really Mexican", but I am happy to prove them wrong. I found this place in Yelp, and I can say unequivocally that it is as good as almost any pozole I had in Mexico!

They look like they have a number of other interesting items on the menu, so I will be back.... but if it's Pozole you are craving, this is absolutely the place. Gracias y salud!
author: Todd M.

description:
First off the portions are huge. I had the birria and it was good.  My friends had the caldo de res and they loved it. Let's not talk about the hand made tortillas and the berries drink. 

The only complain I have is that they didn't have any spicy salsa for the birria because for God sake its a Mexican restaurant. We love spicy food!
author: Jessica U.

description:
We were recommended to try Gallardo's by a friend who had been there before so we thought we'd try it out.

We went this past Saturday with expectations of great Mexican food, something that I absolutely love and seek out wherever I can.  Being from San Diego and having visited some of the best Mexican food in the USA, I was very disappointed in Gallardo's.

I ordered the carne asada plate, which to me is the sign of a good Mexican restaurant if done right.  It was brought to me completely well done to the point of being tough.  There was no sear, which told me it was either boiled or pan fried in its own juice.  It was absolutely bland with NO salt added whatsoever.  I kept trying to pair each piece with other things on the plate just to get some salt.  Nothing helped.  Also, the beans were cold and the rice was clumpy.  A fresh plate from the kitchen shouldn't have food that's cold if it's not meant to be.

My husband ordered the enchiladas and the corn tortillas were chewy and dry as if they had been sitting out all day.  There was little salt and flavor in his dish as well.  There was a minuscule amount of enchilada sauce as well and you'd expect them to be drowning in it.

The biggest issue was lack of salt and seasoning of any kind.  I shouldn't have to pile other things onto the carne asada just to make it taste better; it should stand on its own.
author: Jake B.

description:
Great Mexican comfort food. 
Who can say no to handmade tortillas?!
author: Jessica D.

description: This post must be bumped up to avoid their customers from being scammed by the POSSIBLE dishonesty of the waitresses. What I am about to address may have been an honest mistake, but should not go un-noted. As avid restaurant-goers should know, restaurants add gratuity on the bill for big parties. I am completely okay with that, except that the bill they gave us wasn't a conventional bill, but just an empty paper with only a dollar amount. There were no line items of the dishes we ordered or mentioning of gratuity being added as part of the bill. If this is their everyday practice, I have no doubt in my mind that some big parties unknowingly pay extra tip on their bill. This is a typical way for servers to make extra tip money as I have seen this being done before. They did apologize, but still PLEASE BE AWARE WHEN GOING TO THIS RESTAURANT WITH A BIG PARTY. Food was good though.
author: Phil K.

description: Hands down my favorite mexican food place in the city. It is an intimate family owned and authentic spot where every dish I have is better than the last. The decor isn't gimmicky (which I don't mind sometimes) and it lets the food and kind family service be the stars of the show. I know from personal experience that this family is very giving to their community as well. Micheladas are stellar and outside seating is perfect for a little Sunday Funday. Love this place.
author: Katie S.

description:
This place is a hidden gem and will now be in my regular rotation of eateries in the Mission. 

After a night of heavy drinking, birria was needed. Having never sought it out here in the Bay Area I was skeptical, but this place hit the nail on the head. Birria, a gordita, machaca con huevos, and chips and salsa were everything the doctor ordered to fight the battle of my hangover. My only, tiny, almost irrelevant complaint? Cash only!
author: Hector L.

description: Love this place! The food is so good and the people are so nice here! Cash only so make sure you come prepared.
author: Travis J.

description: Best Birria I've ever had- just like my moms. I got the Birria in caldo (stew) which gave it more flavor. What made this plate even more heavenly was the tortillas, fresh off the comal!
author: Marlene C.

description: First of all the ambiance is like I'm in my grandmas kitchen... the owner is always so sweet asking if our food is good. So I love that right off the bat. But let me tell you their pozole here is LIFE!!!!! & if you're hungover the micheladas also are a must have. You won't regret eating here.
author: Jane W.

description: Excellent food. great prices and service.  Friendly staff.  I highly recommend their beef soup. (caldo de res).
author: David G.

description:
Nothing to write home about here...

Street parking in this neighborhood was challenging. The $9.50 Guacamole & (4) Chips will tie you over while your selections are prepared. At $2.50 I love the Jarrito - Tamarind Soda with natural flavor and real sugar.

At $8.75 the De harina con carne (flour quesadilla with meat) is thick, rich and heavy. 

At $13.75 the Chicken Fajitas looked okay but tasted really quite plain and arrived with no guacamole or sour cream. Its side salad was dry and with out dressing of any kind. Not to mention the three tortillas that arrived much later did so cold inside a steamer.

With only two tables of customers I expected much better food and service. We might give them another try time sometime in the future. If you choose to dine here, good luck, I hope your choices come out better than ours did. Four photos are attached.
author: Caesar A.

description:
Amazing authentic Mexican food! It's still relatively untouched by hipsters. When I walked in, there were tons of families and old friends chatting with the servers. Very unpretentious and we must keep these places near and dear. 

My friend ordered the pozole and wowow the flavor was incredible. They serve a ton of spices and garnishes to go along with it, and it's a perfect meal for a cold San Francisco day. I was craving a quesadilla so I ordered a carne asada one with sides of beans and rice. It was literally just cheese and beef and it was the best quesadilla I've had in a while. The rice and beans were cooked perfectly and I was amazingly satisfied. They serve complimentary tortilla chips which is becoming pretty rare so cherish that. 

The servers are extremely welcoming and friendly and I felt like I was in someone's home. The meal was less than $20 for two of us and I was honestly shocked because everything is usually so inflated in the city nowadays. 

I was hesitant to write this review because I don't want this place to get too popular lol but the food is too good so I had to share. 

Cash only and they don't have an atm in house so bring $$$$
author: Stefanie S.

description: Sweet little spot on the edge of the mission. I think the best thing here is soup and stew. My wife and I both loved our posole. The salsa was fantastically fresh and spicy, but it's served in a little pot you have spoon out of instead of dip, which was very odd. Service is absolutely delightful.
author: Marcie K.

description: Today I came to have dinner with my family and I enjoyed it very much I loved how the waitress came over and asked for a few minutes after giving us the menu she recommended a few items in the menu and then left gave us a minute when she returned we play store order and it didn't take so long to get here she brought us drinks and was very attentive with my boys even though they're so little she still kept them in mind I enjoyed the food it was delicious and well seasoned and my children enjoyed it as well and they are very picky eaters so I recommend you next time you can't decide what to have for dinner come and place the visit to Gallegos and enjoy a wonderful environment
author: Laura M.

description:
I don't recommend coming here for tacos, although the portion is huge, I was not happy with the tacos I got. Ordered the carne asada and the meat was way too dry. The michelada was ok.
Came in @ 3:00 and only a couple of tables occupied. I was immediately seated and my order was quickly taken. I see that everyone was like kind in a rush. Nobody check me even I was finished a long time ago. Everybody was just so busy. I was waiting awhile so I wrote this review right here. 
It's better if you come here with friends and have a lot of things to talk about coz you will have a lot of time to hang around. May be it's just me. I was just passing by and I was hungry andI was alone.
Oops, check still not here, so I finally approach the counter to get my bill. It's $32 for 2 tacos, a michelada and a pozole to go, it's actually not bad for the amount of food I had. Fyi, the pozole was really good I'm giving this place 4 stars.
author: Marlen B.

description:
This is a great authentic Mexican restaurant. Being from southern Arizona, I feel like this is the most familiar style from the Sonoran region of Mexico. Besides providing consistently quality Mexican food, it has an indescribable authentic taste while the staff give that family feel. 

Give this place a try and you won't be disappointed. Be sure to have a Mexican coke to compliment the excellent soup, taco, or plate you're in the mood for. I prefer the flautas, rice, and beans plate (yes I'm a gringo). Cheers.
author: Re W.

description: First time here and we will be coming back for sure! Best pazole I've had since moving to the Bay a year ago!
author: Shana B.

description: Pozole here is incredibly meaty, but so good. Cactus & eggs are the best I've found so far. Do not bother with the tacos - they aren't bad, but everything else is so good that they pale in comparison.
author: Hawley S.

description:
3.5 stars. Great value. I had the famed Pozole here (pork stew with hominy). I love the flavor. The pork quality could be better but pretty good for the size and portion. If you get this dish, ask them to put a bit less hominy in the soup to be a more balanced dish. Do pile on the condiments to make it delicious!

The best Pozole in the Bay Area is at Comal in Berkeley...
author: Rebecca C.

description: This is the best pozole I have ever had in my life. After living in Mexico for a year, I thought it would be difficult to find pozole as good as what I tried there. This is better, and it is prepared with such love that I will definitely be coming back.
author: Kevin A.

description: Wow just wow! So delicious. Im sooo satisfied with the chicken soup aka caldo de pollo !! I recommend all there soups. So good to eat when recoving from an illness
author: Liset O.

description: Great food, fair pricing, clean, good service.
author: Robert M.

description: Go here on Saturday and get Birria and a Michelada. Sit outside, enjoy it, and then tell your friend about it.
author: Varun S.

description: I love having breakfast at Gallardos Mexican Restaurant in the Mission. I like Mexican food a lot although I seldom get it for breakfast. Gallardos is the exception to the rule and the reason is because this place rocks! I love getting the goat Birria al Horno (baked shredded meat & tortillas for wrapping as well as light stock for dipping. The staff members are also very attentive and friendly no matter how many special requests I ask for. They are always very nice, not only to take our order but also to check in and make sure we are enjoy our orders. I don't know if they usually do that but I quite adore this place! I would recommend checking out Gallardos. I am sure you'll find something to love about this place.
author: Abel S.

description:
Nice food.
Shrimp come with the skin.
Tortilla chips come last.
Dont serve water automatically and when I asked they bring just one water and I was with a partner that didn't get.
author: Ohad K.

description:
Excellent corner restaurant where a table full of cops were enjoying a meal too!  You know if they are here the food must be pretty good.

Sampled a beef taco with excellent fresh salads.  Mild Flavors but not totally flavorful.  Good value.
author: Susan C.

description:
I love this place!

It's near my work. Since I only have a half hour lunch and have to eat at work, I always get my food to go. The restaurant is lovely, though and the wait staff are really friendly, so I'm really looking forward to "eating in" some time.

My favorite item is caldo de pollo (or chicken soup to us gringos.) The large is very big and comes with TWO WHOLE LEGS. A great broth and nice veggies, make this a wonderful soup for a cold day, OR when you're fighting a cold. With the garnish of lots of cilantro, limes, chopped onions, along with plenty of corn tortillas, it is a great meal all by itself.
author: Mike D.

description: Awesome birria, home made tortillas, and micheladas! This is the place to be after a nightout. The food here is delicious and satisfying. Service is fast and the staff is really friendly
author: Erika G.

description:
Gallardos is a little slice of urban utopia.  From the minute you walk up to this place and see its wonderful sidewalk garden you know that this isn't a run-of-the-mill burrito shack.  Inside it is gorgeously decorated with beautiful stars of the silver screen all over the walls.  It is a very warm, colorful, and inviting atmosphere.  

A great place for large group dinners to celebrate since they have lots of seating and a great atmosphere for that.  The food is wonderful and the chef's are high-quality and seem to enjoy their work.  This place reminds me of how a business should be and can be run.

With lots of unappealing, overcrowded whip-cracking mexican food places around the Mission, Gallardos stands out as a real breath of fresh air (figuratively and literally).  I feel good about supporting them and the business they run.  

and let's not forget the food is high-quality with very decent portions and an excellent amount of variety in the menu.  Get your order to go and enjoy eating outside with the garden.  Its really a win-win :)
author: Thomas T.

description: Delicious! Very friendly service, authentic, and big portions for small price!
author: Barbara G.

description: Holy portions batman! Really, they give you a ton of almost everything. We split some tacos (don't get the pork one, it's dry) and some birria (quite solid, be generous with the supplied toppings) and some huevos y nopales which were probably the highlight. As always, I wish the plate came with more beans, but I am insatiable devourer of beans.
author: Misha T.

description:
My review of the Restaurant. My sister picked this restaurant because she said that they went there years ago. It's kind of like off of Mission and 18th between Shotwell. It's kind of in a not safe area kind of ghetto place, but it's good to go during the day they have a lot of pictures. The food is semi good. I give it 2 star on the service because they only speak Spanish and the tables were dirty and it took us 10 minutes to try to get someone to clean it they speak broken English which was hard to communicate.

So, hopefully when you go here, someone is fluent in Spanish & English. They have broken English, and they could understand, and you just point to the menu lol and hopefully they get it right. I've had better food but this is a little bit home cooking I guess. 
And we all enjoyed it, it was good it held us until we ate that night.
 The one thing that looks really good and tasted homemade were the corn tortillas that reminded me when I was little when when my mother used to make them.
Now those were good and the homemade salsa that was on fire it's not hot at first, but then all of sudden your mouth is burning. I give that a three star
Thanks for Reading! ~ Liz~  :)
author: Lizzie G.

description: Amazing food and incredible atmosphere  There's no place else to go for authentic food and such welcoming service. This place feels like home
author: Citadale D.

description:
Love this restaurant! The food was great and the service was even better. Had a great time getting to know the family who runs this restaurant over a few beers and incredible enchiladas.  
 
PS: Try their Micheladas (AKA: Mexican Bloody Mary with Beer) and ask for shrimp on the side! Amazing!
author: Chris K.

description: My favorite for birria, menudo and pozole on the weekend. Always fast and friendly service. Parking is usually a nightmare but it is worth it.
author: M. D.

description: Clean restaurant and a good menu.  Hard to find parking and for us, even a place to sit.  Even harder to place our order and we had to call out to place it as we only got menus, not coffee or offer for something to drink while we perused the menu.  When we did finally place our order it was written correctly but we received a taco with beef and not pork carnitas that was on the final check.  The plate was complete with salad, crema and guacamole though it did not say so.  A slice of tomato had the green pit still in it (Yuck). Served with large, thick corn tortillas and that was good.  Beef was dry and lacked flavor.  Not much spice in the given sauce for the chile relleno.  Better than most Mexican places but our experience was less than excellent.  Probably because it was full.
author: Mike N.

description: Very good Mexican food and service. Brought my family party of eight and we all very happy
author: Pedro C.

description:
I used to go to this location when it was chavas and was sad to see it burn down. But the people that run Gallardos are so nice.
I go here for the Menudo and the fresh tortillas. I like how there is no hominy in the soup and I request more cartilage and they take care of me. 
My friend did order the chips and we both thought that they were cheap. Would have been better if they made them there or bought them from La Palma on 24th. Good thing I don't go for the chips : ).
Until I find a better place for menudo that comes with fresh homemade tortillas, I am a solid customer.
author: fritz k.

description:
Cheap authentic Mexican cuisine. Honestly one of my fave spots. 

PS. Massive portions! You can probably share a plate between two people.
author: Maria R.

description:
Hey Gallardos... Gayardos.. Gurados.. ?

I admit, I still don't know if I am pronouncing your name right.
I did learn it means "brave" - correct me if I am wrong.

It's unfortunate you are a block from another decent mexican place (el tepa) since I think lot of those who work near me never make it past tepa to give you a shot.

But let me say this, I think you are fantastic. The food is rich and your dishes sure seems a lot more authentic than most places. Of course being that I am not Mexican, people can take that for what it is. 

First and most important, I rave to others about your POZOLE. nom nom.
The soup is good and hearty, but what really gets me is the assortment of items you give with it: Onions, diced cilantro, tortillas, tostadas, lime, spices and so on... I just pour those bad boys in to the soup and it becomes the most hearty soup you can find. Excellent on a cold day, or hot day, or whatever day. 

I also tried your beef soup, which was pretty good as well. All I can say is, please never skimp on those extras because that is what makes it extra special. These soups come out fast because they got a giant pot boiling in the back.

Your meat plates are also pretty good. I've still not been able to try your weekend specials but perhaps one day.

The live music is a fun plus.
You are a cool little spot with good food. 

See you next time Galardas

.. gallardes?

WHATEVER
author: Paul L.

description: I woke up a little hungover and craving Mexican food. Used yelp to find an authentic Mexican breakfast place, which I've yet to find in the six years I've lived here. This place is off the beaten track and it is delicious! I got the #12 a chili relleno and an enchilada combo plate (with rice, beans, and salad). I ordered it all cheese but added chorizo and fried eggs on top. I think the server thought I was a little crazy for that, but again I was hungover, and it paid off because it was so satisfying! They provide you with fresh salsa and tortillas... order chips also super yummy! Large portions... looking forward to the left overs in my refrigerator
author: Natasha R.

description:
I came in today with friends for my birthday brunch, and I just wanted to say thank you. Thank you for the warm hospitality and venue, prompt service, and delicious food. Since moving from LA, I was worried I would not be able to find an authentic mexican restaurant. 

LOVED the table salsa, the fact that they serve fresh tortillas, the spanish speaking staff and golden age mexican cinema posters. 

My only complaint is that los chilaquiles rojos were not spicy and not topped with cotija cheese, but every traditional dish in Mexico is interpreted differently based on region, so I'll let that one slide!
author: Daisy M.

description: The food was not terrible for the price but they were out of many items which surprised me. The menudo was not one of favorites. The bathroom isn't kept clean as well. If you're a germaphobe stay away.
author: Imani M.

description: Caldo de res was awesome.  Good Michelada too. The place is very laid back; it's almost as if you're seating somewhere in Mexico in the 50's.  Service was good Cash only.  Expect a line on Sunday mornings.
author: Roc A.

description: Delicious, comforting albondigas soup and attentive service. Granted it was not very busy on a Weds at lunch!
author: Stephanie L.

description: That pozole is out of this world. I think it might need to become a weekend tradition for me. The broth is deeply flavored, has a good tartness, and they serve it up with a ton of limes and the best corn tortillas. My only complaint is that my partner and I never want to order the same thing so we often have a hard time figuring out what second dish to order. He's tried the chorizo eggs and the heuvos rancheros and we always like the pozole the best.
author: Victoria J.

description: Chicken quesadilla is the Best! They cook the chicken with lots of flavor and ingredients. I've also had the steak torta, which was bomb as well.
author: Karla G.

description:
That feeling when you finally satisfy your pozole craving.  One of the most authentic mexican spots Ive eaten at in a long time, and I don't have to fly back to L.A. or Mexico to have it. 

Pozole - Great! Very flavorful, comes with standard fresh verdura. I agree with some of the other reviews that the pork quality could be better and tender, but overall, solid!

Nopales con huevos - Seasoned perfectly. Large portion served with healthy amount of rice & beans.

Another plus - tortillas are freshly hand made! :)
author: Roman V.

description: Jus got the menudo. It's real y'all. Not fatty. They don't put hominy in it. The tortillas are fresh. It's real.
author: Cindy F.

description:
Stopped for lunch. Very good. Table Salsa'a hot. enchilada and Chile Relleno were good.  

BTW Cash Only
author: Mark M.

description: Served cold food.  Sent back only to have a big messy inedible blob of crap returned to me.  When I pointed it out, she says OK and proceeds to charge me full price.  Other patrons all Hispanic treated like royalty while my white self sat ignored.  Seriously, people walked in after me, ordered, ate and left while I'm begging for attention.
author: Lynne P.

description:
When I think of eating Mexican food out, the only place I would go is GALLARDO's!!
Why because they give you food made from scratch and portions are more than you can finish !!

Last dish I order was Camarones Tapatios, and man they were nicely grilled with the right hit of my favorite chile, Chipotle!!
author: Leticia Z.

description: Just like family.... They greet you with a warm entrance and give the feeling of " you've found the spot". Worked at a window and door shop down the street ( until recently relocated). And always recommend gallardos for the best authentic plates.... I HIGHLY recommend this fine restaurant. Good people, good food. Thank you gallardo family!!!
author: Ben P.

description: nothing beats great sit-down Mexican food, and a great big bowl of albondigas is my measurement for being great.
author: Jubilee D.

description:
Great Mexican restaurant.  The breakfast is very hardy and will last you all day. Love the inside colors and classic pictures.

Thanks for the great food!
author: Ian A.

description:
POZOLE with homemade tortillas is Awesome!!! Caldo de Carne is also very yummy. 
Very family friendly, kids love their tacos and sopes. Bean cheese appetizers is awesome with a chilled Negra Modelo. 
Defiantly a great place to visit for a hearty meal.
author: Dee Q.

description: It seems like this place has a knack for really yummy soups and stews. Not only by the photos, but also in person everyone seemed to be ordering and enjoying the pozole, caldo de res, or albondiga soups, me included. I ordered the traditional pozole rojo. It warmed my soul with it's delicious, spicy flavor, along with it's tender pork. I actually found myself sucking the fat out of the bones MMM. On the side came Mexican oregano, chili flakes, raw white onion, chopped cilantro and limes to add to the soup as you pleased. There was also raw cabbage, radish, sour cream and tostadas, which I thought were unnecessary because it came with warm tortillas and so many other fillings and toppings. Also, the salsa was off the chain! This dish would have been put over the edge if the tortillas were homemade! Though super friendly, the service was slow as heck. This won't stop me though, I'll definitely be back here to try another soup.
author: Adriana G.

description:
Today i decided to order from this place. Read the reviews seemed like it was going to be delicious. 

We ordered the menudo and the beef soup. 

Honestly was the worst menudo i have ever had. 
If your Mexican i recommend going somewhere else. 

And she forgot to put the oregano and chile in our bag even after i asked her to and she repeatly told me is was in our bag. 
And to top it off she was rude for no reason. 

Take your business else ware.
author: Paola R.

description: We love the fresh homemade tortillas and the place was spic and span and we especially love the homemade beans great food and great service. Best breakfast we had in San Francisco.
author: Pat D.

description: The food here was amazing! The portions were big and the service was great! Tortillas are handmade & the agua fresca (cucumber) was refreshing.  So glad we found this gem, can't wait to come again! If you're visiting San Francisco this place is a must!
author: Jessica J.

description:
My mom kept nagging about wanting Menudo and Gallardo's was recommended by a close friend of mine. I didn't know what to expect going in for lunch on a Saturday. I went with my family so we called ahead to save some Menudo plates (apparently they sell out quickly!) Gallardo's was packed upon our arrival, however, the hostess was really kind and was able to sit our group of 6 within 15 minutes at max, which didn't seem too long seeing how busy the restaurant was.

From the beginning the service was great. We were accommodated at a larger table with enough eating room for all of us. My younger siblings ordered quesadillas, which they seemed to enjoy. The grown ups got the Menudo dish. Let me tell you, their Menudo is seriously authentic and delicious. If you're a Menudo fan, you've gotta try Gallardo's (but don't tell your friends because I want this place to be my little secret!) 

As we were leaving my cousin started talking to the owner, who seemed genuinely interested in his customers satisfaction. Apparently, Gallardo's was previously at a different location in the Mission which we had gone to in the past but couldn't find after it closed. It was crazy to find out this was the exact same place we used to go to for Menudo. I'm just happy we found it and my mom got to satisfy her cravings. Will definitely be coming back.
author: Stefany Z.

description:
The long and short of it is that I stopped by for pozole (small $8.75, CASH ONLY) for lunch the other day and it was okay. Not as good as the now closed Chilango on Church St or Nopalito. 

Why was it only okay? The small is actually a pretty big bowl of brothy soup. They serve it with a side dish of cabbage, diced onions, radishes and limes (for the soup), plus sour cream and crispy tortillas (to east on the side). You also get bowls of dried oregano and chili flakes to sprinkle in. I thought the soup was spicy and flavorful but the pork was almost besides the point. It didn't have much meaty flavor. I didn't think there was as much depth and complexity in the soup as in the other places mentioned.

It's also a weird size - quite big for one person but not quite big enough to share substantially. I kinda wish there was a $7 or less option. Then I'd feel like it was much better value. Paying to get a lot of food that's difficult to take home for leftovers is not a good deal. Possibly I'm the only person with this problems.

Chips & salsa were good. Salsa was super spicy. Also comes in a condiment jar so you're supposed to spoon it onto each chip.
author: Jean K.

description:
My MIL was craving authentic Menudo ... which we found was hard to find in SF. Ended up here based on Yelp reviews, and sadly, were disappointed. On the plus side, it was edible. Perhaps it's just not what we're used to. 

The nice thing was that they had quick service and the food was fresh.
author: Esme C.

description: Luv this place! Food always hot, lots of flavor and the service is wonderful. I say wonderful because I luv going to a restaurant where you feel at home with your favorite person taking care of you and your food.
author: Pet R.

description: Excellent food and general owners. So I was walking by a Gallardo's recently in the Mission and thought, I would love to have one of their amazing burritos. So I stopped in and ordered a super chicken burrito. Then I realized that I didn't have any cash and they didn't accept credit cards. Before they made it, I told him that asked them to cancel the order. Instead, the owner prepared a delicious super chicken burrito and gave it to me. Told her that I could afford it but just didn't have the cash. She just smiled and said it was fine.She didn't ask for anything in return. I just thought it was very generous. Plus it was an amazing burrito that I share with a friend. Love this place.
author: Janet K.

description: Happened in on this fab neighborhood restaurant as I was biking through the Mission. I usually don't like sit-down eateries in this area because of the ambiance. The run of the mill taquerias serve decent food, but their bare bones interior are bereft of any charm. I usually grab and go. Yet at Gallardos I felt like I was in a lovely residential area in Mexico, lingering over my plate, watching happy Latinos slurping Menudos over a beer. I even tried to practice my Spanish and the lovely servers, las mujeres, obliged. I sat outside and had huevos con chorizo, which I didn't care for, because the eggs virtually disappeared into the chorizo mix. But, this might be my fault as I think the server asked how I like my eggs in Spanish, but I didn't catch her super speedy drift. The woman who shared my table ordered a pozole and it looked out of this world. So next time I will try one of the sopas. The menu is definitely full of interesting dishes that I would like explore.
author: Firat Y.

description:
7-16-16
Came back again and brought the two younger kids. I got the chilaquiles with green sauce. So good and more than I could eat (which doesn't take much unfortunately). They obviously use their homemade tortillas in this dish and the thickness of them still absorbed the sauce and stayed chewy and hardy. The girls shared the pancake plate with added eggs and bacon. Next time I'm getting the caldo-another dish that looks super yummy. 

The atmosphere was fun and bright and every dish that came out was not skimpy thats for sure. The owner heard me ask another patron about their dish and so he brought me my own small bowl of Birini (lamb soup) and I had a plate of Huevos Rancheros in front of me that I ordered. I am stuffed beyond with the yummiest Mexican food that beats anywhere I've tried in SoCal. The beans and rice were so fresh and flavorful. The orange juice was freshly squeezed and a thick bright orange color. I had to display my whiteness and ask for some butter to go with the hot fresh corn tortillas I couldn't resist. I wish I spoke Spanish to tell the owner really how good this brunch was! I saw the owner walk around and great all his customers with a smile and friendly service. Would definitely go back. Food was DELISH. There wasn't a bad thing we tried- and we tried a lot!
author: Trisha R.

description:
"What can I get for you, my friend?"

Mom and I visited Gallardo's yesterday for lunch (after mistakenly getting on an eastbound bus from Twin Peaks instead of westbound!) Always on the hunt for posole, I was pleasantly surprised to see that they offered the flavorful pork-chile-hominy stew on weekdays (whereas it is traditionally served only on weekends).

Service was very amicable; our sharp, bilingual waitress spoke to all of her customers with warmth and friendliness. The food came out shortly after a side of crispy tortilla chips, fiery salsa, and two passionfruit agua frescas. And OH MY GOD. The posole was better than those I've tried in Mexico City. A plethora of fixings - chopped cilantro, diced onion, quartered lime, sliced cabbage, cubed radish, red pepper flakes, sour cream, and Mexican oregano - accompanied the savory, rich, meaty broth of the pozole. The pork inside the soup was tender and good quality, and the hominy was strangely addictive to munch on. 

I had a bit of Mom's enchilada plate - the beans and chicken were full of flavor. She joked that there HAD to be MSG in the beans for them to be so savory, but otherwise she really enjoyed her meal.

Better yet - we paid $25, tips included, for our whole meal. Take it from a pair of Texans - Gallardo's is the destination for authentic, tasty Mexican fair in Mission.
author: Chris W.

description:
Honestly, Gallardos has become my favorite Mexican spot in the mission. Especially love their soups and their caldo de res. Massive hunks of delicious, succulent beef and my favorite beef stew in town (and I've tried a lot of them). Come with a big appetite!

The service is a little finnicky - you often have to flag down a waitress to get your order in. But they greet you with a smile and are extremely friendly. Love the decor as well.
author: Ben G.

description: OMG Mexican breakfast! Not those fake breakfast burritos. The real thing. Family owned and run, super authentic, excellent customer service! They take care of you here.
author: Irving S.

description:
We came for lunch today & had some beers and a Pacifico michelada to start. Good start! The waitress also brought chips and salsa for us to munch on and the salsa was good, just a little spicy... So we ordered a side of guacamole for the table and mixing them was great. 

While we were waiting for our food some little mariachi guys came in and played some music for a while, my grandparents would love this place! Live music definitely makes the ambiance better. 

I got the large pozole - perfection!  Our waitress recommended it & I'm so glad she did. I love that it came with all the mix ins on the side, I will definitely be back for this to cure the next hangover... I just wish it was closer to my house. 

Nick got the chile verde burrito, it's huge! He took half to go. I had to try a bite and boy was it yummy! I'd recommend it. You can get t regular or super for 1$ more - add guacamole, sour cream and salsa I think it was. Do it! 

The service was great and everyone was very friendly. Can't wait to go back and try something else on the menu.
author: danielle a.

description:
Had Sunday brunch, the food was amazing! Waited for a little over 5 minutes to be seated. Once we ordered the food arrived in just under 10 minutes. 

Ordered the birria, chilaquiles, and huevos rancheros. The chilaquiles were perfectly crispy and soo yummy! The huevos rancheros were extra cheesy just how I like it. The tortillas were the best handmade fresh tortillas I've ever had. Their coffee was delicious with a hint of cinnamon. 

The service was good, it was packed. My only dislikes were that they charge for chips and they weren't fresh. The chips tasted stale. Also, it was inconvenient that they only accept cash on the weekends, but the food is reasonably priced...so that's good.
author: Christina O.

description: Yesss. Micheladas menudo is everything.. and nothing better than athentic Mexican food  .. can't stand all the white people thoe  ... good service good food good price it don't get any better ..
author: Reyna C.

description: Incredible authentic Mexican restaurant in the Mission!  I highly recommend the chicken enchiladas in red sauce.  The place is cash only and the service can be a bit slow, but the homey feel and excellent food more than make up for it!
author: Desiree J.

description:
My husband and I came here both days this past weekend! We had such a great experience and food on Saturday, that we decided to come back for dinner the next day. This is a family owned and operated business, with some deep roots in SF. The customer service is genuine and spot on. 

Now, let's chat about the food. AMAZING! During the last 2 days, the husband and I ordered: pozole, shrimp cocktail, pescado de diabla, and some sort of animal infused burrito (all him). The pozole was delicous! From what I heard, his shrimp cocktail was divine as well. My pescado dish had an extra kick of spicy per my request, and I absolutely loved it.  

I used to come here a lot when it was at its previous location on 14th street for lunch. Since it moved, and since I've moved I have forgotten what a gem this was. We will be coming back here as regulars.
author: Tracy C.

description: Excellent, friendly service. I ordered the Chorizo and egg burrito, regular size. Huge size for the money. Great value. Very tasty. I always pop in here to pick up two burritos before heading in for a tattoo appointment. One for me, one for the artist. We both love the food.
author: Chef C.

description:
I stumbled upon this place via a morning Yelp search to find a place to cure my hangover born of a Halloween party the night before.

I had been aimless scrolling around Yelp for over 10 minutes before the words huevos rancheros popped into my mind and that was the end. I entered huevos rancheros into the search box and Gallardos was the first place that popped up - for good reason.

I'm not from Mexico, so take for it what you will when I call this place authentic, but it sure does feel like it to me. Fresh, homemade corn tortillas, spicy salsa, the scent of fresh food cooking wafting through the room. What else could you want? I, of course, got the huevos rancheros with a "side" of their birria, their weekend special. 

Now birria and I have a very long relationship - the first time I tried it I was down in Rosarito, Mexico on a spontaneous weekend road trip down to Mexico. The circumstances of why our group thought it would be a good idea to drive from San Francisco to Mexico on a whim, I am unsure. However, what I am sure of is the fact that it was on that trip when I discovered what birria was and fell in love. For those of you who don't know, birria a Mexican soup, usually cooked with lamb (this is also the way Gallardos serves it), and it is amazing. It's exactly your answer to a Saturday/ Sunday morning hangover and the best comfort food. Now, I am not lamb's biggest fan, and I was hesitant to try the birria here for fear if it being too gamy. Gamy it was, but in a good way. I could eat it and the spices - chiles, etc., did a good job of easing the intensity of the gamy flavor. Gallardos serves the birria with their thick tortillas and those alone are to die for.

We walked in and got a table immediately, but as we were eating, a short line formed out the door. Also of note is that this place is cash only, so don't forget to grab some before you come. I'll definitely be coming back here next weekend.
author: Patricia K.

description:
One of the many benefits of working in the Mission District is the abundance of Mexican restaurants and taquerias to choose from on a daily basis. While my co-worker and I Yelp'd our way to find a new place to try, he brought up Gallardos, a Mexican restaurant that he had visited a few weeks prior and couldn't help but recommend. I'm not one to ever turn down a new Mexican spot and we made our way down to their 18th Street address.

Given that this was a Monday, I can safely say that 1 of the 2 of us were hungover, and I was already salivating over the pictures fellow Yelpers have uploaded. We were both surprised by how busy the restaurant was until we realized it was a Martin Luther King Jr. day and a holiday for most people. Luckily since we were a small party, we were quickly seated without having to wait.

The cute waitress brought over some menus and took our drink order and brought us some chips and salsa. The menu is rather long and has plenty of options with many entrees around the $10 mark, with only a select few costing in the $15 range. After looking over the extensive menu, I settled on combination plate #3, enchiladas rojas. The plate includes two enchiladas with your choice of chicken, steak or pork, covered in red sauce and served with rice and beans. I chose to go with chicken and as far as beans, you have pinto, black, and refried to choose from.

Unfortunately this is where service began to deteriorate. I understand that the restaurant was busy but it didn't seem slammed and even receiving our two drinks felt too long. Once we did receive our drinks, we were out of chips and that took just as long. As for our food, it took longer than we expected but luckily for us, we weren't on a time crunch. I will admit that once the food hit the table, it looked mouth-watering delicious. Also, I did appreciate that both plates were delivered together and not staggered.

A few bites and I will say that everything tasted A-OK, it was by no means earth shattering but it was better than your standard taqueria fare. The ingredients felt fresh, the pinto beans were done right, and the enchiladas were stuffed with shredded chicken, and topped off with plenty of salsa roja and smothered in melted gooeyness. It was definitely the right choice for a hangover Monday, not to mention the side of rice and guacamole included on the plate. My co-worker was equally pleased with his plate and once everything was said and done, we were both stuffed.

However as far as service, it was pretty much nonexistent after our food was served. It was difficult to try and get refills on water and some extra napkins. It seemed rather odd considering that the rush was dying down but for whatever reason, we seemed to be forgotten. Even getting the bill was difficult and took a few minutes, but nonetheless, I'm open to give Gallardos a second chance. The food felt homemade, fresh, and was reasonably priced given the sit down service and portion size. I hope to have a better experience, service wise the second time around.

Ambiance/Decor: 3/5
Food: 3/5 
Service: 2/5
Price: $$
Overall: 3/5

Pros:
+ Large menu with most prices around $10 with a high of $15
+ Food tastes authentic and fresh
+ Sit down, restaurant service 
+ Nice atmosphere and decor
+ Reasonably priced
+ Beer and wine available
+ Credit cards accepted

Cons:
- Slow service
author: Alexander E.

description:
Portions are generous and pricing is not bad for a spot in the Mission. It's on the corner and parking was pretty easy for me on an afternoon day. I had two tacos, which were around $4 each - and was stuffed after. My boyfriend had a regular burrito that was super big and left him stuffed as well. The salsa was delicious but too spicy for me to handle, so the waitress brought us a more soupy one that had less of a spice - yum! Service was friendly and I can't wait to return to try all the other items on the list :)

Also, cash only!
author: Amanda C.

description: Like no other Mexican food experience except my grandmas house and Mexico. So much flavor in their Caldo de Pollo and their Nopales con huevo was delicious!!! I brought some caldo home and it was even more delicious as leftover. Service was average but it all worked out. Micheleadas were a perfect finish to a delicious home cooked Mexican meal!
author: Christine S.

description: Best traditional Mexican food in SF, thanks Juan & family! Try to order the house made tortillas!
author: Jacques T.

description:
Amazing burritos! So filling, flavorful, and tasty!   Service is great, just slow as it's very busy. 


Great atmosphere.
author: Herald A.

description: I call on Mother's Day and order Menudo and it was the best. The food is delicious I will always come back here. the people were great the lady at the front (cashier) was very polite and very nice.make sure that I have everything and asked if I needed anything else.
author: Hector O.

description: Real Mexican Food!!  I feel the best I have ever had in my 72 years of life.  They make their own salsa and is the best; warning-has a kick to it.  You will want to buy some to take home.  The service is very good.  I am from the Riverside, Ca. area and will definitely eat at Gallardos every time I visit San Francisco.     Steve
author: Steve W.

description:
Manager/owner: "You really like to take pictures"

Me: "That's because I'm visiting from NY, the land of no pozole, so I really need to capture this moment."

Manager/owner: "Oh, the NYTimes actually did an article on our pozole and menudo." 

Me: "Not surprised. It's THAT good."
author: Tammy K.

description:
I just don't think this place has very flavorful food. It's charging SF prices for casual Mexican food. I could deal with that if the food was memorable in any way, but it's kind of not. I think El Techo has better quality food for lower prices. Sure, it's not a sit-down place, but if you go here at a busy hour, you really shouldn't expect very prompt service either: A colleague and I recently had lunch here on a workday it it took over 90 minutes. 

So in my mind, you should either pick a non-sitdown, or if you really want to sit, pick a "fancy place".
author: Justin A.

description: Me and the family have been coming to Gallardos since it was on 14th South vannes the pictures all over the wall bring a really good vibe into the place as well as the customer service. The food is always good too. Best breakfast spot to go to
author: Paula G.

description:
Yay for outside seating! I can finally enjoy a bowl of menudo with my trusty canine companion.  

The menudo here is exquisite! It was seasoned perfectly...spicy, hearty, and piping hot...delish!
They do not hold back on the meat either...I ordered a small and was barely able to finish it...probably because I ate about half a dozen homemade tortillas.

My bf had the birria de chivo al horno. He was very impressed...he says its probably the closest in flavor to the stuff served in the motherland (Mexico). Our only gripe is the choice of salsas...i wish they had a better selection. Maybe something with toasted chile de arbol & garlic? That would put this place over the edge for me...oh well. 

The service is impeccable. The food is delivered quickly and always with a friendly smile. I highly recommend this place to my paisanos looking for authentic tasting Menudo & Birria de chivo. 

Oh and it's reasonably priced too..I'll definitely be back.
author: Gina G.

description:
As members of the Fond of Goat organization, needless to say we went to Gallardo's for their Birria de Chivo which is served only on Saturday and Sunday.  The dish - which was a dry ("al horno" = oven roasted) version, came with tortillas for wrapping, condiments (lemon, cilantro, onion, oregano, chili flakes), and a bowl of goat broth ("caldo") fir dipping.  It was first rate.  We had the same dish at the nearby San Jalisco a few weeks back and it is difficult to pick between the two.  The SJ dish had more bones, which I like, although Gallardo's version made for easier wrapping in the tortilla.  SJ came with beans and rice while the Gallardo's version did not include any sides.  All in all a toss up - best to try them both!

We did really enjoy Gallardo's space (the warm walls and high ceilings really made for a pleasant dining environment on a beautiful day like today), and their staff was very attentive and welcoming.
author: Mike M.

description:
You know an ethnic restaurant IS legit when you walk in and everyone stares at you. Not because your fly is down or you have a protruding camel toe but because they're probably wondering WTF you're doing there. Blame it on Yelp.

We walked into Gallardos in search of authentic Mexican comfort food and were welcome with stares from all the native patrons. No hipsters in sight. We were definitely in the RIGHT place. 

A family owned and operated restaurant, Gallardos seems to be popular among families as we saw many Mexican families partaking in Sunday brunch. They have a fairly large dining area split into 2 sections so it's good for groups. Gallardos has on overwhelming menu: Mexican breakfast items, American breakfast items, omelettes, salads, soups,  tacos, quesadillas, burritos, sandwiches, tortas, burgers, seafood plates, meat plates, and combination plates BUT the thing to order is their sopas (soups). They'll soon be moving to 18th street so do call ahead of time to see if they're still open at their current location across from Foods Co.

Cash only on the weekends.

They were out of Birria, their specialty so I ordered a large bowl of Menudo (weekends only - $9) and Mr. NSS ordered a large bowl of Caldo de Res ($9). While we waited for our order, we received a complimentary basket of chips and salsa: http://bit.ly/16cQtua. The warm chips were thin and crunchy with just the right sprinkle of salt. Like crack, it was purely addicting. We also ordered Guacamole ($5.50) which as you can see should have never been served in the first place: http://bit.ly/12UFrqs. 

My eyes glistened as our two steaming bowls of soup arrived. Comfort in a bowl, the menudo was chock-full of tenderly soft honey comb tripe in a robust crimson mild chili broth: http://bit.ly/ZfTiTZ. There was also a huge pig's feet and knuckle that was a gelatinous sensation in the mouth. I know pig's feet may sound gross to many but it's truly a delicious delicacy that should be tried at least once. Menudo is my ultimate Mexican comfort food and this was by far the BEST bowl of menudo I've had.

The Caldo de Res is meat and potatoes in a bowl: http://bit.ly/11QCA0I. With large beef shanks, potatoes, tomatoes, carrots, zucchini and corn in a homey broth, the Caldo de Res is served with rice and beans, making it one hearty dish.

Aside from the no bueno Guacamole, everything was 5 star worthy. The sopas were amazingly comforting while the service was very warm. The owner even came up to our table and started speaking in Spanish to me (apparently she wanted me to try her desserts). 

Sorry Ms. Owner Lady, despite having taken Spanish in high school, the extent of my espanol is "Donde esta el bano" and "Yo quiero corona y patron". 

The two most important things to know when traveling in Mexico right?
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Yikes! They're moving to 18th Street? (photo: http://bit.ly/12OPLQT) Well, that's what I get for waiting so long to try Gallardo's which is a nice, hearty stroll from my home in its current location across from Foods Co. After all, it's been around for only 53 years, clearly a fly-by-night operation. Jamie W. and I came here quite by accident when we were buying our 72-packs of toilet paper at Costco. After we started getting peckish waiting in the ridiculous line there, we walked over to the SoMa Streat Food Park just a little too early since none of the trailers were open. That's when I remembered Gallardo's as a place to get some morning menudo. The place is bustling on Saturday morning with a steady stream of regulars coming in and out of the two-room dining area (photo: http://bit.ly/15OdRhB).

For lack of options, we were seated at the largest round table in the middle of the floor. The desayunos (breakfast) menu is robust and comprehensive, much like it is at SanJalisco on South Van Ness and 20th (photo: http://bit.ly/11Mnxnx). But instead of colorful Mexican folk art decorating the walls, Gallardos offers what appears to be enlarged movie stills from Mexican cinema. I like it, just a bit of glam to go with your super-burrito. Jamie ordered the $8.25 Machaca Con Huevo, a very full plate of scrambled eggs mixed with shredded beef, onions, tomatoes and bell pepper with rice, refried beans and warm tortillas on the side (photo: http://bit.ly/12OPjls). Hearty eating and diner-ifically good. It's Saturday, so of course, it was the $9 grande bowl of Menudo for me.

The rich red broth came from a mix of roasted tomatoes pureed with dried chiles (photo: http://bit.ly/Z2hbOI), and there was a generous amounts of tripe and beef bones swimming inside. I sprinkled the cilantro, diced onion and dried oregano, and the result was definitely one of the better bowls of menudos in town (photo: http://bit.ly/183aUJk). Along with the warm tortillas, that should have been a complete meal, but I was so seduced by the lure of the $3 Puerco (Pork) Taco that I ordered one. What arrived was a meal in itself, a corn tortilla piled high with shredded carnitas, queso fresco, tomatoes and avocado slices (photo: http://bit.ly/11rw1zT). Whoa, that was a lot of food but the perfect way to laze on a weekend. Besides we had 72 rolls of toilet paper in the trunk, so we were good.

FOOD - 4 stars...great bowl of menudo, satisfying huevos make for hearty eats on the Mission/SoMa border
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...love the Mexican cinema photos all over the walls
SERVICE - 4 stars...very kind and attentive as they buzz around the tables
TOTAL - 4 stars...I'll follow them to 18th Street, I'm sure
author: Ed U.

description:
Arrived this morning, a Saturday about 11 am, and it was packed.

Service was super quick tho and our food arrived fast.

We had the lamb soup, that's only on menu Sunday and Saturday, a chile verde burrito which was huge, could only eat half.  And I had a chile relleno and chicken taco 

The food all tastes great.  The cucumber drink was fabulous (a little too sweet tho, I think they added too much sugar, but I beleive it was very authentic).

Once we got our food we never saw our waitress again.

....the reason I dinged a star, is we waited forever for the check so we could leave. I finally walked up to register to ask how to pay (which wasn't easy with all the tables to maneuver around) and told to sit down they would bring  it, then I had to go back to the register to pay.  It was all so awkward.
author: Foodlover B.

description: Wow. Giant portions overall and the Pozole was truly incredible. Amazing place and locally run and owned. Will be back.
author: Ben G.

description:
This place is great!

Came here for breakfast, and was instantly greeted by the nice staff. The service continued to be great throughout our meal.

The food is authentic, the atmosphere reminds me of family parties growing up, and everyone seems genuinely kind here.

I recommend coming here for breakfast or lunch.
author: Lindsey C.

description:
Stopped by here for dinner and were disappointed with 2 of the 4 dishes we ordered.  Steak salad - while the salad was a generous portion, the steak was chewy and flavorless.  Chile Verde De Puerco - the pork was dry and chewy as well.

Chips and salsa were excellent.  Tried to order a side of guacamole and was surprised they didn't have any...The kids didn't like the shredded chicken used for the quesadilla. We ended up going down the block to El Tepa for a fish taco afterwards.
author: M G.

description:
their pozole had way too much cubes of pork.. however the broth was really good!

the soup came out a bit cold.. 

lots of tables.
parking is tough.

this place is CASH ONLY so make sure you pass by an atm before hand.
author: Kris A.

description:
A local family run mexican restaurant that is cash only.  Nothing fancy, authentic cuisine. Go on the weekends for the menudo.

Beware that yelp warned me they had a low Sanitary score.

Picks:
Enchilada rojas ($8.75) 2 chicken enciladas in red sauce with rice and beans.  Good size, real meat and beans.

Just OK:
None

Would not reorder:
None

Overall - Good
Food - Good
Decor - Good
Service - Good
Value - Very Good

Would we come back - Yes
author: Ellen H.

description:
Came here for lunch with the bf. Close by to our office. This was our first time dining at a Mexican restaurant (we always eat at taqueria when we want something more common) Food was very good! Flavorful & fresh. BIG portion for a reasonable price! Its always pack and busy (which is a good and bad thing... when its too busy, the service might be a little slower than usual! 

Definitely would come here if we are craving for mexican food!
author: Peter C.

description: I used to go to this place and it had better food so I wanted some fresh made tortillas and birria but they didn't have none. So I look at the pictures on yelp believe me nothing of what the pictures show are true the menudo tasted old then I asked the waitress what day was the menudo cooked and she said today. It was a lie it was sticky and nasty. Being a cook myself I know about food. The quesadilla plate that they offered was nothing like the one in the picture it was half of a quesadilla cut in a square. The plate on yelp for the shrimp soup, had nothing to do with reality. It had 4 shrimps a lot of soup to cover that they didnt put enough shrimps they put big pieces of carrots. I don't have nothing else to say about this place.. I won't be returning to this place. Oh and I heard from my family they always go to this place I guess they didn't like me or my kids but I can say they have really good servers that's why I give them one star I hate that some Mexican restaurants in the beginning they offer you the best food then later on cut corners in the food it doesn't taste the same I think that it should be authentic for the prices that we're paying for food believe me I am Mexican so I know flavors
author: Maria H.

description: Fantastic flavors and sincerely cared that we had a great experience. That is special, especially in a city that makes you feel guilty for ordering a coffee at a coffee shop.
author: Kevin O.

description: One of the only authentic Mexican restaurants in San Francisco. With homemade tortillas and big portions you can never go wrong with any dish. This is a family run business and will give you that home feel and service.
author: Roberto H.

description: Rainy day brunch for 6 that I won't be forgetting soon. Heart the large black & white photos of classic Mexican entertainment stars(?) along the walls. Heart the loud serenading guitarists randomly walking in & out. Hearted my sabotender omelette + fresh 6-juice blend that matched the deep red tablecloth. No matter what you order, eat some of it on the handmade tortillas = must-try.
author: Dan B.

description: Basic Mexican food. I had to get up and ask for chips because they charge for them and you don't get them complimentary. They didn't bother to tell us either as most restaurants don't charge for chips and salsa at least when you dine in. Parking is of course difficult. They give you can sodas at $1.50 each because they do not have a soda machine. Restaurant only takes cash and their ATM machine doesn't work. Alot of old ways to do business.  I had to get up to ask for napkins, extra plates, and it took awhile to get someone to take our order. The plus side is that the staff is kind to their customers they just took awhile to get back to us when we asked for stuff, took long to bring the bill, and really didn't come check on us.
author: L S.

description:
Mexican food heaven. This place was packed with a local old timer mission crowd. Fortunately the outdoor tables were wide open.
I had the abondigas soup. It a ridiculously big portion. Meatballs delicious.  Broth perfect. With it I got a bunch of hand-made tortillas, bowl of dried oregano, bowl of cilantro and onion and home-made salsa - yummm.  Accompanied with a Negra Modella the tab was $13.
author: Ric S.

description:
This was the worst dining experiences I have ever had.

It started out fine, with a mostly empty restaurant and our option to pick any table. There were a ton of options on the menu, so I decided to pull up Yelp and see what's popular. That's when I was immediately presented with a notice that this restaurant has a history of poor results on their health department visits. I should have run but we were  in a time crunch and needed to get dinner right away....bad decision. 

I ordered enchiladas and my partner ordered a burrito. Food came out quickly. Too quickly. The food was obviously not fresh. The beans and rice on my plate were clearly microwaved, crusty around the edges and inconsistent temperature throughout. The chicken in my enchilada was dry, tough, and tasteless. The pile of wilted greens could only pass for a salad on a public school lunch tray. My partner's burrito was cold throughout. I will say the presentation of the burrito was excellent. We never received chips, but for some reason we were given extra tortillas.

No one ever paid attention to us after delivering food,  so we could not complain. I was also unable to get a refill on my iced tea. 

The kicker was the end of the meal we waited a full half hour for our bill. The restaurant was only a third full, but no matter what we did we couldn't get the attention of any wait staff. After a while my partner got up and directly asked a waitress to bring our check. She never did.

He got up again and was completely ignored. So he grabbed a menu from the front of the restaurant, we figured out how much we owed, threw down cash, and left.
 
I wouldn't recommend this restaurant to anyone, ever, for any reason. The food was worse than mediocre, the wait staff were completely oblivious, and the ambience was nothing to write home about.  

Pick any other Mission Mexican restaurant but don't come here.
author: D D.

description:
We go there and the place was packed, the waitress didn't speak much English which was fine and luckily speaking Spanish got us a communal table by the door, whew the last few seats left before the line up began. Good sign. I can see everyone getting menudo or birria as it was the weekend. The prices were very good on everything on the menu but we came to try what we wanted the Birria. They had 2 types one "al horno" - meat separated from the broth or the big gigantic bowl of goat soup.  We went for "al horno" as I like to make my own tacos with it. It was heaven. Just like I remembered it. Love this place. The poor waitress was very busy, the place was pretty big and there appeared to be only 2-3 waitress maybe family run. It took us forever to order even though we knew right away what we wanted.. so difficult to get her attention too but the food made it all worth it. Another tip is the Jugo mixto the fresh squeezed orange and carrot juice is to die for. So yummy. This was a fantastic start to our search of birria in SF!!

Value 5/5
Atmosphere 4/5
Service 2.5/5
Quality 4.5/5 
overall 16.20
author: Nina S.

description:
Went to a Mexican restaurant with the dietary restriction of not being able to have any dairy products (or anything that contains calcium). Oh boy! 

The reviews for this restaurant were great and I don't eat a lot of authentic Mexican food so I really wanted to stop by here being that it was also in the Mission. 

I ordered Pozole because of the reviews and because of hearing all my Mexican friends talk about it. I asked the server how to eat it because she also gave me tostadas, tortillas, cabbage, radishes, and sour cream. She laughed and was so awesome and told me the ways people like to eat it. It definitely made me enjoy my dish more and enjoy the service I was getting. 

The Pozole was delicious. So hearty and filling. I could not finish it! 

My friend got two tacos. They were pretty big tacos too! He got one carne asada and one chicken taco. He says he enjoyed those as well. 

I paired my Pozole with a Negra Modelo (recommended by our awesome server). 

Yum yum. The restaurant itself is very cute as well. With marigold walls filled with classic black and white pictures of, what I'm guessing are, movie stars. 

It was about $8 for the Pozole, $3.75 each for the tacos, $4 for my beer. My side of the meal was about $14 including the tip. Pretty good!!!
author: Jess D.

description:
FYI, Cash only on Saturday and Sunday
